awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social-Environmental Feedbacks Between the Use and Governance of Water and Soil in Dryland Irrigation Megaprojects
awd_abstract_narration:
This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement project will examine dryland irrigation megaprojects and related changes in the use and governance of water and irrigated land. Irrigation megaprojects in arid landscapes feature prominently in agricultural development worldwide. Planning and policy entities often focus on the economic benefits of irrigation water for farmers. However, irrigated soils are often central to ecological and social conflicts that follow the construction of irrigation districts. Such conflicts include reduced soil quality, water contamination via agricultural runoff, and displacement of regional farmers by investors' large land acquisitions. Therefore, this research will investigate the social and ecological effects of irrigation megaprojects and the related governing policies and practices of irrigation water and soils. This research will contribute to scholarly and policy considerations of social-environmental feedbacks in governance. The broader impacts of this project will (1) work toward improved irrigation infrastructure development, (2) strengthen management of irrigated land to ensure increased sustainability of soil and water resources, and (3) encourage policy that ensures more equitable access to irrigated land. During this research diverse university students will receive training in mixed methods research. This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

	This dissertation investigates the interactions and feedbacks between irrigation megaprojects, soil management practices, and soil and water governance. Scholarship of environmental governance related to irrigation has focused on issues of water access and control. While important, more scholarly attention must examine the centrality of soils within irrigation megaprojects. The coupling of and tensions between water and soil use and governance require detailed empirical examination that leverages key literatures within geography and the spatial sciences, particularly environmental governance, coupled human-environment systems, and feminist political ecology. Three questions guide this research: (1) How does access to water from irrigation megaprojects shape soil management practices, specifically crop selection, crop rotations, and applications of agrochemicals? (2) How do social and environmental stressors inform soil management practices? (3) How do social and environmental stressors feedback into environmental governance? This research employs a mixed methods approach including change detection analysis, environmental archival research, participant observation, a survey, farm transect walks, and semi-structured interviews with farmers, irrigation managers, and government officials. This research project will provide new insights regarding sustainable and equitable approaches to irrigation development and governance in dryland areas in Colombia and elsewhere, including the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The doctoral research examined changes in and power relations of land use and tenure, water distribution and access, and agricultural seed diversity (agrobiodiversity) tied to irrigation megaprojects in three of Colombia?s five largest irrigation megaprojects. Synthesizing data from mixed methods research conducted throughout one year of in-site research, the dissertation advances scholarship on land and water equity and sustainability in rural development, with particular attention to the impacts of irrigation development on the livelihoods of historically marginalized peoples. The project investigated three principle questions:

  1. How has governance-mediated access to water from irrigation megaprojects shaped soil management practices over time, specifically crop selection, crop rotations, and applications of soil amendments and agrochemicals?
  2. How have social and environmental stressors informed farmers? soil management practices over time in Tolima Valley irrigation megaprojects?
  3. How do experiences of environmental stressors feedback into soil and water governance in Tolima?

The research design adopted a case study methodology to span three neighboring, river diversion, canal irrigation megaprojects in the central agricultural region of the department of Tolima. Two megaprojects operating since the 1960s produce the majority of Colombia?s paddy rice through highly mechanized, industrial production. The third megaproject, the Tolima Triangle, remains partially completed after the government suspended its construction in 2014. In contrast to the northern two districts? monocropped fields of paddy rice, the municipalities within the bounds of the Triangle project are known for high rates of agrobiodiversity, most notably native varieties of maize. Furthermore, the Triangle megaproject was designed to benefit a region with high rates of malnutrition and poverty and in which more than 85% of residents identify as Indigenous Pijao. To investigate the aforementioned questions, the co-PI conducted the following methods:

  • textual analysis of rural development plans and policies,
  • 294 household surveys of agricultural producer households,
  • 81 interviews with agricultural producers and key informants,
  • 12 months of participant observation,
  • soil samples of 20 paddy rice fields and five fields with diversified systems, and
  • classified vegetation change analysis of land use change within the Tolima Triangle since 2014.

Data analysis revealed three principle findings. (1) In contrast to the assumption that irrigation megaproject development simplifies agricultural landscapes, many residents in the Tolima Triangle have responded to landscape changes by maintaining and reinforcing commitments to agrobiodiversity, especially the diversity of native maize varieties. Notably, women residents play a particularly prominent role in the promotion and conservation of agrobiodiversity through activities in community seed exchanges, culinary practices and the cultivation of richly diverse home gardens. (2) The establishment of irrigation megaprojects shifts patterns of water distribution and land access and use. Without governance of resource access, such changes may disproportionately benefit agricultural producers with more economic and political power. Moreover, in areas with significant populations of Indigenous residents or other historically marginalized person, rural irrigation development may further entrench social-environmental intersectional unevenness in access and use of water and land resources. (3) Opposing neoclassical economic theories of rural development still promoted globally, this research demonstrates that land rental markets in areas of irrigation megaprojects do not lead to more equitable rural resource use. Rather, the mutual value creation of land and water resources within irrigation project areas and associated high land rental costs can result in small-scale and landless producers? exclusion from agricultural livelihoods. These findings may inform rural development policies for future irrigation megaproject development, and more specifically supports environmental governance that addresses land and water as linked resources and works towards resource use equity for historically marginalized producers or those with less social-environmental power.

The outcomes of the research are multiple. In terms of development of co-PI Baumann and her contributions to United States and international research, Baumann published three sole author articles, co-edited a special issue, and published another co-authored article. Two additional co-authored articles are under review as of the submission of this report. Baumann has presented various parts of the research at academic conferences in the United States, England, Colombia and Mexico. She has been invited to give guest lectures and research talks in university labs and graduate classrooms in the United States and Colombia. Moreover, the findings of the dissertation research were communicated via outreach mediums of blog posts, newspaper articles, radio broadcasts, video presentations circulated on social media and public presentations in the case study communities.

The grant has also created paid research training opportunities for five undergraduate and one graduate U.S. students as well as for one undergraduate and two graduate Colombian students.
